articles.headline: Boat to Safety Is Death Trap to Sri Lankans
articles.snippet: The testimony of refugees who stayed adrift in the Indian Ocean for nine days is a rare glimpse into the war.
articles.abstract: The testimony of refugees who stayed adrift in the Indian Ocean for nine days is a rare glimpse into the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAKINADA, India  Fleeing the bitter end of a quarter-century-long war, the refugees turned to a boat. It was first a shelter from artillery shells, then a frail craft to safety. Finally, it became a coffin.

articles.headline: Pakistani Army Poised for New Push Into Swat
articles.snippet: Residents were flooding out of the Swat Valley by the thousands as the government prepared to mount a new military operation against Taliban militants there.
articles.abstract: Residents were flooding out of the Swat Valley by the thousands as the government prepared to mount a new military operation against Taliban militants there.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Residents flooded out of the Swat Valley by the thousands on Tuesday as the government prepared to mount a new military campaign against Taliban militants and as a much-criticized peace accord with the insurgents fell apart.

articles.headline: Money Fund Managers Are Accused of a Fraud
articles.snippet: Federal regulators said the managers of the Reserve Primary Fund failed to disclose its vulnerability after the collapse of Lehman.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators said the managers of the Reserve Primary Fund failed to disclose its vulnerability after the collapse of Lehman.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday accused the father-and-son team that operated the Reserve Primary Fund of securities fraud, contending they had lied to investors when the fund “broke the buck” last fall and created a near panic in the money market fund industry.

articles.headline: As Unemployment Growth Slows, a Recovery Could Stir
articles.snippet: After a stretch of unrelenting bad news, the economic signals have been more mixed lately, leading those who have been pessimistic to reassess.
articles.abstract: After a stretch of unrelenting bad news, the economic signals have been more mixed lately, leading those who have been pessimistic to reassess.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ben Bernanke sounded more optimistic on Tuesday than he has in a long time, and President Obama has talked about glimmers of hope. The stock market has risen 34 percent from its 2009 nadir.

articles.headline: Bright Spot in Downturn: New Hiring Is Robust
articles.snippet: In spite of the recession, the U.S. economy is actually generating jobs at a healthy clip, with many major employers hiring.
articles.abstract: In spite of the recession, the U.S. economy is actually generating jobs at a healthy clip, with many major employers hiring.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone knows the grim news  unemployment in the United States has jumped to 8.5 percent, a 25-year high, and is racing toward double digits. Since November, the nation has lost more than three million jobs.

articles.headline: Doctor Sounds Alarm Ahead of Tobacco Vote
articles.snippet: A pulmonologist is not waiting for peer review to publish his research contending that cigarettes pose a higher risk of lung cancer than they did before the surgeon general declared them a health hazard in 1964.
articles.abstract: A pulmonologist is not waiting for peer review to publish his research contending that cigarettes pose a higher risk of lung cancer than they did before the surgeon general declared them a health hazard in 1964.
articles.lead_paragraph: For three decades, Dr. David M. Burns has written and edited some of the seminal work on tobacco science and the hazards of modern cigarettes: surgeon general’s reports, National Cancer Institute monographs, World Health Organization studies.

articles.headline: As Investors Circle Ailing Banks, Fed Sets Limits
articles.snippet: Seeing opportunity in the nation’s struggling banking system, private equity firms are lobbying to change federal rules that limit their control.
articles.abstract: Seeing opportunity in the nation’s struggling banking system, private equity firms are lobbying to change federal rules that limit their control.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAINSVILLE, Mo.  No one seems to want to own a business in this dusty, windswept corner of rural America, population 370, with its crumbling sidewalks and boarded-up storefronts.

articles.headline: Plan to Sell Chrysler to Fiat Clears Bar
articles.snippet: The judge overseeing the bankruptcy of Chrysler approved the bidding procedures advocated by the company and backed by the White House.
articles.abstract: The judge overseeing the bankruptcy of Chrysler approved the bidding procedures advocated by the company and backed by the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: The judge overseeing the bankruptcy of Chrysler on Tuesday took a significant step toward allowing the sale of most of the automaker to Fiat, approving the bidding procedures advocated by the company and backed by the Obama administration.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Jonathan D. Glater

articles.headline: Mississippi Farmers Trade Cotton Plantings for Corn
articles.snippet: A shift has emerged in an area tied to the same crop for generations as United States farmers plant the least cotton acreage since 1983, which in itself was an anomaly.
articles.abstract: A shift has emerged in an area tied to the same crop for generations as United States farmers plant the least cotton acreage since 1983, which in itself was an anomaly.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENWOOD, Miss.  Cotton is no longer king of the Mississippi Delta.

articles.headline: Bank of America Needs $33.9 Billion, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: The government has told the bank that it needs the capital to withstand any worsening of the economic downturn, according to an executive at the bank.
articles.abstract: The government has told the bank that it needs the capital to withstand any worsening of the economic downturn, according to an executive at the bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government has told Bank of America it needs $33.9 billion in capital to withstand any worsening of the economic downturn, according to an executive at the bank.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Interrogation Memos: Inquiry Suggests No Charges
articles.snippet: A draft of a Justice Department report found serious errors of judgment in secret memos authorizing brutal interrogations, but opposed prosecuting the authors.
articles.abstract: A draft of a Justice Department report found serious errors of judgment in secret memos authorizing brutal interrogations, but opposed prosecuting the authors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  An internal Justice Department inquiry has concluded that Bush administration lawyers committed serious lapses of judgment in writing secret memorandums authorizing brutal interrogations but that they should not be prosecuted, according to government officials briefed on its findings.
articles.byline: By David Johnston and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Civilian Deaths Imperil Support for Afghan War
articles.snippet: Concern increases about American raids as the Obama administration prepares to increase forces in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Concern increases about American raids as the Obama administration prepares to increase forces in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  American airstrikes that Afghan officials and villagers said Wednesday had killed dozens and perhaps more than 100 civilians in western Afghanistan threaten to stiffen Afghan opposition to the war just as the Obama administration is sending 20,000 more troops to the country.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Taimoor Shah
